moves.1. e4: My oppomemt moves up his king's pawn to free his queen and kinsgide bishop...
moves.2. Nf3: ...and he develops his kingside knight to attack my pawn, with the King's Knight opening...
moves.2... Nc6: ...so I defend it with my queenside one, with the King's Pawn game...
moves.3. Nc3: ...and he moves out his queenside knight, with the Three Knights game...
moves.3... Nf6: ...and I move out my kingside one, with the Four Knights game...
moves.4. Bc4: ...and he moves out his kingside bishop, placing it in front of his queenside knight, in conjunction with the Italian Variation...
moves.4... Bc5: ...and I copy that move, keeping with symmetry...
moves.5. Ng5: ...and he advances his kingside knight to line up a second form of attack on my kingside bishop's pawn...
moves.5... O-O: ...so I castle kingside to cover it with my rook...
moves.6. Bxf7+: ...but he captures it with his bishop...
moves.6... Rxf7: ...so I capture the bishop with my rook...
moves.7. Nxf7: ...which is instantly captured by the knight...
moves.7... Kxf7: ...so I capture the knight with my king, for a total equal value trade of six points apiece: my pawn and rook for his bishop and knight.
moves.8. Qf3: He develops his queen, pinning my kingside knight...
moves.8... Nd4: ...so I move its twin to attack her...
moves.9. Qd3: ...forcing her to move out of the way, unpinning the knight in front of my king...
moves.9... d5: ...and I now move up my queen's pawn to free her bishop, and to attack my opponent's king's pawn...
moves.10. f3: ...so he covers it with his kingside bishop's pawn...
moves.11... Ne6: Now I retreat my knight from the 5th rank, allowing my bishop to control the squares leading to g1, and to prevent him from castling kingside...
moves.12. Nd5: ...and as he attacks the knight in front of my king with his...
moves.13... Qh4+: ...but at first I can't understand why I moved my queen to the far side to check the king here, with my remaining knight en prise...
moves.14. g3: ...where the obvious response was to block with the pawn that started in front of his kingside knight...
moves.14... Qh3: ...and so I move my queen onto the square the pawn relinquished control of...
moves.16. Qc4+: He attacks my king with his queen...
moves.16... Kd6: ...so I move him close to my bishop...
moves.18. Qc4+: ...and she attacks from the previous position...
moves.18... Kd6: ...so I move him back again to guard my bishop...
moves.19. d3: ...but this time he moves her pawn, to avoid the possibility of a threefold repetition...
moves.19... Qg2: ...so I move my queen into the space the blocking pawn vacated...
moves.20. Rf1: ...forcing the rook to the only safe place...
moves.20... Bh3: ...so the queenside bishop comes up to help her...
moves.21. d4: ...and he moves his queen's pawn to clear the path for the queen to cover the rook...
moves.21... Bxd4: ...so my bishop captures the pawn, so mine stays close by my king for extra protection...
moves.22. Qd3: ...and as he keeps his queen on the diagonal covering the rook...
moves.22... Qxf1+: ...I capture the rook with my queen...
moves.24. Kxf1: ...and he captures my bishop with his king. That's why I moved my queen on the attack on move 13: to win a rook for a bishop, which is how I won that exchange, leaving me ahead by a pawn.
moves.24... Rf8+: Now I move my remaining rook onto the open f-file to take control of it, and attack the king...
moves.25. Kg2: ...and as he moves off the top rank...
moves.25... Rf2+: ...I can advance my rook to the 7th rank to a square covered by my bishop...
moves.26. Kh3: ...and as he hides his king near his kingside pawns...
moves.26... Rxc2: ...I can hoover up a pawn on the queenside.
moves.27. a4: He advances the pawn in front of his rook...
moves.27... Bxb2: ...so I capture its neighbour with my bishop, forking his bishop and rook...
moves.28. Ra2: ...so he moves his rook forward to place my bishop under a second form of attack...
moves.28... Rxc1: ...so I capture his with my rook...
moves.29. Rxb2: ...and he does likewise, leaving a single-rook and pawn ending, with me having a three pawn advantage.
moves.29... b6: I move up my queenside knight's pawn to prevent the rook from advancing to my second rank...
moves.30. Rf2: ...so the rook moves across to the only open file with no other pieces...
moves.30... Ke6: ...and I move my king across to cover the f7 square...
moves.31. Rf8: ...but the rook proceeds to my bottom rank...
moves.31... Ra1: ...so I line up its pawn with my rook in the far right-hand corner.
moves.32. g4: He moves his kingside knight's pawn...
moves.32... Rxa4: ...so I complete the obliteration of his queenside pawns, leaving me with a four pawn advantage, with my extra four pawns passed.
moves.33. Kh4: He moves his king towards the action...
moves.34. Re8+: ...so the rook attacks my king from behind...
moves.34... Kd5: ...so I move my king up, and keep his pawn guarded...
moves.35. Kg5: ...and as he moves his king away from the edge of the board...
moves.35... h6+: ...I move up my kingside rook's pawn to distract him...
moves.36. Kh4: ...so my opponent moves him back to the edge.
moves.36... e4: Now I move my king's pawn to the 5th rank, as I decide I should make my numerical advantage count...
moves.37. h3: ...and he advances his rook's pawn to try to put up a fight...
moves.37... Kd4: ...and I move my king to help his pawn...
moves.38. Re7: ...and my opponent moves his rook back one rank to hoover up my pawns...
moves.38... e3: ...so I advance my king's pawn to the 6th rank...
moves.39. Rxg7: ...and although the rook hoovers up one of my pawns...
moves.39... e2: ...my king's pawn advances to the 7th rank...
moves.40. Rd7+: ...and although the rook checks my king from behind...
moves.40... Ke3: ...my king moves behind his pawn to give it a clear run. 41. Re7+ would be followed by 41... Re4, so the rook cannot get back in time to prevent a promotion, and can also offer to exchange rooks: 42. Rxe4+ Kxe4 43. any e1=Q.
moves.41. Rxc7: Although the rook hoovers up a second pawn...
moves.41... e1=Q+: ...my king's pawn makes it to the 8th rank, and queens, instantly checking my opponent's king...
moves.42. Kh5: ...forcing him to the only safe place...
moves.42... Qa5+: ...so my queen retreats to the far side to attack him again...
moves.43. Kxh6: ...and as he takes the bait of my kingside rook's pawn...
moves.43... Rf6+: ...my rook moves back to force him towards my bottom rank...
moves.44. Kg7: ...and as he moves to attack my rook...
moves.44... Qg5+: ...my queen moves across to help it...
moves.45. Kh8: ...and as he backs into my near left-hand corner...
moves.45... Qh6+: ...my queen attacks him one last time...
moves.46. Rh7: ...and although the rook shields him from her...
moves.46... Rf8#: ...there's no escaping my rook, as it finishes the job for a queen and rook checkmate.
